titleStmt.title: The Story of My Life
The Story of My Life, August 1891
titleStmt.author: Saleh Bin Osman
[Glave, Edward J., 1863-1895]

monogr.title: St. Nicholas: An Illustrated Magazine for Young Folks

imprint.publisher: The Century Co.; T. Fisher Unwin

div.head: THE STORY OF MY LIFE.
div.p: (As told by Saleh and recorded in shorthand.)

I BORN in July 9, 1871. My mother was dead when I three years old. When I was one year older, I go to my mother sister, and stay with her. When I get four year old, my father send me school to read Koran, and then when I seven year old I begin to read the Bible, and finish when I eight year old the Bible. The schoolmaster name is "Shayhah"; over in
America you call him schoolmaster. He change my name and call him "Saleh," mean "honey"; and when I ten year old, I finish all school and went to my father, and takertook me one year to stay with my father. When I get ten year, he takertook me travel to India, Bombay, Calcutta, Bungola, and come back to Zanzibar.

He askerasked me, "Which kinekind business you 795
796 THE STORY OF MY LIFE. [AUG. like?" I say, "l likerlike make shop, fruit-shop"; and then he give me 40 dollar, and I go to my frenfriend [friend] and he give 40 dollar, and then to 'notheranother frenfriend, he give 40 dollar, and then we make bisnessbusiness. We sell cokenutscoconuts, orange, and mango, and sweet lemon. And then my frenfriend he tol'told me "This makermakes dirty bisnessbusiness, much better to buy boat, a little rowboat," and we pay 200 dollar, and that 's all money we got.

When 'MericanAmerican manwah [man-of-war] come, we bring people down; and next time we went to go, the sea very bad, and boat he go down, and one my frenfriends no swim, he wear heavy jacket, and he go down dead. And we swim to manwah, and 'notheranother boat he come and bring us to shore, and all people say my fault, because I at the head of the bisnessbusiness, and I mad. And he say I be likerlikely to get a plent'plenty money quick! And my father was cross-to me because all people say that my fault. I run away and went to MalagascarMadagascar [Madagascar]; and all money I get I got 20 rupee [rupee, 40 ctscents.j in my pocket.

When we 'rivearrive to MalagascarMadagascar, we stop at Noosbay. All French people, and master askerasked me for passage. I brokespoke French. I say, "How much?" He say, "Twenty rupee," and I say, "That 's all money I got." He say, "I don't care, I want twenty rupee, now, quick!" I give it him, and I don't got any money in my pocket. And I went in police station, and soon I see myself, and I set down and cry. When watchman come, askerasked me, "Why you cry?" He think somebody beat me. I told I cry because I no home this country , no frenfriends. He askerasked me what language speak. I say, "I speak Arab"; and he laugh me, and say you can't go far, we no speak Arab in this country [Madagascar]. I stayed there till half-past five, and see him, he bring in tin, a small tin likerlike a cup, and it inside no sugar, no milk. A piece bread he givergave me, and said, "That all I have in my supper. Have no better supper." And I say, "Thank you to God, and thank you to yourself." And then he show me place and say, "You go down there." In evening rain come and sundercomethunder come [thunder come], and I fright. And I don't got blanket, don't got pillow, just sleep in grounground. And when rain come, and I up and I sit down, and I cry.

In morning I went to French town, and I
see big big man, and he say to me, "Hello, boy! what you do here?" Because he know me very well, because I dress different; I dress Zanzibar dress. He say, "You Zanzibar boy." I said, "Yes. I don't know anybody here." He say, "Come with me." And I go to him. And he told me, "I want you to go to my wife, and carry bag, and to go with her all places she go, when she go for walk." This man Frenchman. He name AdmirallyAdmiral Pierre. He fight in MalagascarMadagascar. And he takertook me in his manwah, and takertook me to his wife; and she be glad. She say, "I tried to find Zanzibar boy when I there, to teacher me Zanzibar language."

Half-past four we went down shore, in town, and she buy too much clothsclothes, and guvegave to me, and she told to me, "I want you to throw 'wayaway dirty clothsclothes you got." And I throw 'wayaway, and dress fine.

We sail from Noosbay to Junka, and we fight there for seven day. That was the native MalagascarMadagascar, called "Hover"; yellow, likerlike Chinese. Got two name, the other name we call him "Wambalambo." When we fight we stay there for two mont'smonths. And Madam Pierre she show very kinekind for me, likerlike my mother. And then I teach her in Zanzibar tongue for two mont'smonths, and then she speakerspeaks me very well. When I say something to her she understan'understands. And then she askerasked me everything 'boutabout myself, an'and I told her how I come. She said, "I am very sorry for you, I makermake you happy just likerlike mother." And then she say, "I want you teacherteach me Zanzibar language, and I want you learn MalagascarMadagascar, because when AdmirallyAdmiral go home he will want you interpreter, and on manwah."

He got two boys, and he say, "Now, Saleh, you takertake walk with these boys every day and they teacher you. You go down city, and they tell you name everything." One boy told me something and I put down Arab, and I learn quick in four months. And Madam go home, and she say, "AdmirallyAdmiral, takertake care Saleh, he good boy." And then my bisnessbusiness was carry AdmirallyAdmiral's rifle and glass when we go in shore. And on manwah I have nothing do, and sit down and eat and dress nice. And then he call me, "Saleh, my boy," in Zanzibar language, because he speak Zanzibar first class. One day he call
1891.] THE STORY OF MY LIFE. 797 me in morning and give me letter, and I open and finefind Madam's picture and little gold ring.

Madam go home, write AdmirallyAdmiral, "Please bring Saleh home, we show people, and we send him back to Zanzibar." One day in morning he called me, we go shoot guinea-fowl, and takertake clean and bring to Madam when we go to France. And we went there and shoot one, and he send me look for it, and he forget I there, and he shoot and his bullets come through my ear, and I fall down and cry loud, and he come and lookerlook, and then throw 'wayaway his gun, and call somebody takertake me 'wayaway to manwah. And he takertook care for me, and when I get better he finish his business himself, and we sail for Marseilles, France. And then he ketchcatch fever in sea, and when he go to Marseilles he sick seven day, and he dead. And his wife she was good to me and sen'sent me back to Zanzibar.
I was glad to go back, but I was sorry to lose AdmirallyAdmiral because he was good to me. I was glad to go home, but l was sorry to leave Madam because she nicernice lady.
That all my story travel in MalagascarMadagascar with AdmirallyAdmiral.

My uncle, Tippu Tib, told me much about Mis'r Stanley. He know him. He Mis'r Stanley's frenfriend. When Mis'r Stanley 'rivearrived in Zanzibar, that makermade me to go with him in Africa because I think I travel all same likerlike I travel in MalagascarMadagascar. I find Mis'r Stanley nices'nicest man I ever see. He is strong man, and very clever man. He is a very good shot. He is strong for march. He is clever for caravan. He has six hundred twenty-one Zanzibars, and all likerlike him, all speakerspeak good for him. He think all time for his people. This Dark Forest, we don't have car'agecarriage there, no horse, no donkey, no camel, no railway, you know very well. This travel everybody must carry his rifle, his clothsclothes, tent, and ammunition. And this Dark Forest, all bush and trees very very high, -- big! People live in this Dark Forest, cannibals and pigmies. This
little people, this pigmies are 'boutabout two feet and half big. The pigmies not strong 'noughenough forto grow anything. They makermake iron, they makermake fine powsenpoison [poison], and they go round elephant, because they so small he no see them, and they shoot him in eyes with powsenpoison arrow, and before long he fall down dead. And they go to village and call big natuvenative, we call

Wasamgora and cannibals. Pigmies have no big knife, [and bring other natives] because they got knives to cut elephant. Now this big natuvenative he come cut all meat and divide, and takertake half, and half he leave to pigmies. These cannibals (Wasamgora) eat man the same they eat beef and mutton. And we have cannibal man, he belong to Emin Pasha, and his name we call Binsa. Emin Pasha give him to DocterDoctor Junker and takertake to Zanzibar, and he went with us in Africa. He is not cannibal now.

I think Mis'r Stanley is very fine man. We lose many people in Dark Forest for hunger. I don't forget why I say Mis'r Stanley is very fine man, he think for his people more than for himself. One day he told me, "I think I likerlike my people very much, because my people is my home. If I lose my people I can't go anywhere." All native in Africa likerlike Mis'r Stanley. Ev'rythingEverything he want and do, he call his people, askerask first. And me sure many people say Mis'r Stanley bad man -- all je'lusjealous, have nothing in head, all head full of flies. I see six hundred people myself likerlike Mis'r Stanley, speak well for him. I been three year and half with him, he teach me very well. I enjoy my travel with him. He bring me back to Zanzibar, home. I askerasked him to come to Europe with him. I come for good time with him in Europe. He is here July, and have wife, good heart and fine looking. We all went through Europe, France, Germany, Italy, Switz'landSwitzerland, come back
to London and went to Scotlan'Scotland and Irelan'Ireland and all over Englan'England. He takertook me over here to 'MericaAmerica now, and I likerlike 'MericaAmerica very much. I think there is nice ladies in 'MericaAmerica. And I think there is nice boys and girls. I think they have nice schools in 'MericaAmerica. I believe this is a rich country. I been in New York, Brooklyn, New Jersey, Springfield, Boston, Worcester, Providence, Chelsea, Rochester, Buffalo, Cleveland, Chicago, and too many places in all the country that no have time to say, and I forget his name.

I have no time to tell you how good time I have this country . I like this country very much. I write book in Arab, and I go to publish when I go home. I have no time tell you how fine ladies this country. How fine boys. I'm sure I got something to say when I get home. Goo'-byeGood-bye. I sail Wednesday to Englan'England. Soon as I get to Englan'England I go home to Zanzibar.

p.seg: Of the Stanley Expedition for the Relief of Emin Pasha.
